awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Pulse Dynamics in Fiber Lasers at the Verge of Mode-Locking and in Transition Regimes
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Nonlinear Pulse Dynamics of Ultrafast Fiber Lasers in Transition Regimes 

Non-technical description: 
Lasers with ultrashort pulse durations have found widespread applications in precision measurements, micromachining, biomedical imaging and medical surgery. For any of these fields, it is crucial to be able to monitor and predict the power and laser properties to avoid excessive tissue or material damage. As these lasers feature extremely short pulse durations (on the order of femtoseconds) which exceed the fastest electronic characterization instruments, an existing challenge is to capture the pulse-to-pulse evolution in real-time. The goal of this proposal is to develop new real-time optical characterization methods that can provide insight into the pulse-by-pulse behavior and characterize novel lasers states. These methods can enable new modulation schemes in communication systems while having fundamental impact on laser development and optimization. In addition, the proposed real-time characterization methods can provide powerful analysis tools for continuous monitoring of cell mechanisms, fluid dynamics or chemical reaction kinetics. 
This project also provides an opportunity to train undergraduate and graduate students at the intersection of laser physics, systems engineering, materials science, and real-time characterization to build a new generation of multi-faceted researchers to tackle the interdisciplinary nature of technological and societal challenges in the future. The PI will organize professional networking and mentoring opportunities through a Boston-wide Photonics Networking series that highlights female engineers. This aims to bring together a diverse group of engineers and scientists and to encourage underrepresented minorities in the field. 

Technical description: 
The PI proposes to develop a real-time measurement system to analyze the pulse-to-pulse evolution simultaneously with phase coherence in thulium-holmium doped fiber lasers around 2 micron wavelengths as well as for erbium doped fiber lasers in 1.5 micron region. The proposal aims at exploring and characterizing transient effects, rapid fluctuations and nonlinear pulse dynamics on a pulse-by-pulse basis for ultrafast fiber lasers, e.g. at the verge of mode-locking. A modified time-stretching technique based on dispersive Fourier transform is to be developed to capture pulse behavior on a single pulse scale. Systematic studies aimed at resolving the intricate interplay between different pulse shaping mechanisms in fibers will lead to fundamental insights into pulse dynamics and transient states that can be applied to design novel laser cavities, resolve polarization evolution and optimize performance parameters.

por.por_cntn:
Lasers with ultrashort pulse durations have found widespread applications in precision measurements, micromachining, biomedical imaging and medical surgery. As these lasers feature extremely short pulse durations (on the order of femtoseconds) which exceed the fastest electronic characterization instruments, an existing challenge is to capture the pulse-to-pulse evolution in real-time and to characterize fast transient femtosecond phenomena. Without any established commercial instrumentation, there is limited experimental knowledge about the pulse and nonlinear dynamics associated with resolving transition regimes or any non-repetitive, fast instabilities in ultrafast lasers, in particular for wavelength regimes around 2 um.

We developed a real-time measurement system to analyze the pulse-to-pulse evolution of femtosecond fiber lasers with a focus on wavelengths of 1.5 - 2 um. By combining polarization sensitive analysis with coherence evaluation, the start-up dynamics in an erbium-doped fiber laser were characterized and the transition evolution between multi-pulsing states was captured. For thulium-doped lasers, the spectral dynamics in non-stationary regimes were explored and the impact of birefringent filtering on nonlinear pulse shaping and dual polarization states was analyzed. The formation of states with reduced coherence, marked by multi-pulsing instabilities coupled with pulse collapse as well as explosion states were captured in real-time.

Intellectual Merit

This research enabled critical insights into novel pulse operating regimes where quasi-periodic dynamics can occur for the emerging wavelength regime around 2 um. The intricate and rapidly changing pulse-to-pulse dynamics in thulium-doped ultrafast fiber lasers in multi-pulsing and transient states were captured with the design of a modified dispersive Fourier transform system. The instrumentation development allowed novel fundamental insights into the underlying pulse dynamics and their polarization evolution. Overall, the research offered interesting insights that can be of benefit for critical laser development and performance optimization.

Broader Impact

The proposed studies can directly benefit ultrafast laser designs, especially for applications in micromachining, biomedical imaging and medical surgery. In these fields, pulse fluctuations during short operation time windows need to be exactly monitored and predictable to control excessive tissue or material damage. The developed real-time characterization methods can pose powerful analysis tools for continuous monitoring of cell mechanisms, fluid dynamics or chemical reaction kinetics.

Undergraduate, graduate students and researchers were trained as part of this grant at the interface of laser physics, system engineering, ultrafast phenomena and nonlinear pulse dynamics to be part of a new generation of multi-faceted researchers. A particular focus was placed on recruiting female undergraduate students and exposing them to fiber lasers and their applications. A lab module as well as updates on scientific and technological advances were integrated into a graduate course on lasers. Hands-on optics experiments geared towards freshmen engineers from a variety of majors as well as high school students were developed. The PI offered a Boston-wide Women in Photonics Networking series targeting female engineering students and scientists to receive mentoring, networking and professional career development to encourage more underrepresented stakeholders in the field.
